Award.AwardTitle: Reckoning with the Risk of Catastrophe-Workshop scheduled for October 2012 in Washington, DC.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
The steering committee of the seventh Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft / National Science Foundation Research Conference, Reckoning with the Risk of Catastrophe, scheduled to be held October 3-5, 2012 in Washington, DC, asked Andrew Lo to put together a proposal to support American involvement in the research conference. The purpose of the conference is to facilitate true intellectual collaboration between American and German scholars. The bulk of the funds that Lo is requesting is to cover participant support costs for American scholars to attend the workshop. Approximately one-third of the American scholars selected to attend the workshop are students or early career professionals. The event will provide these students and junior researchers with an invaluable international experience.

We know a great deal about disasters because disaster research has existed for more than 60 years. But the scale of recent events - particularly Hurricane Katrina, the financial meltdown, the Japanese Tsunami, and the Fukushima nuclear problems that followed - have led scholars to seek new knowledge to better understand and manage potentially catastrophic risks. Researchers across countries and disciplines are beginning to investigate the root causes and common threads of such disasters, reinvigorating the study of catastrophic risk, and moving us closer to finding practical solutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Deutsche Forschungsgemeinshaft (DFG) and National Science Foundation (NSF) supported a research conference, Reckoning with the Risk of Catastrophe, October 3-5, 2012 in Washington, DC. This was the seventh in a series of conferences sponsored by the principal German and US fundamental research funding agencies.

The emphasis of the conference was on scientific advances to help societies understand, assess, and manage their vulnerabilities to catastrophic risks across multiple disciplines and contexts. Although we know a great deal about disasters because disaster research has been going on for at least 60 years, the scale of events like the financial meltdown, the Japanese tsunami, and the Fukushima nuclear disaster that followed have led scholars to question the conclusions and scope conditions of more traditional research. There is an urgent need to better understand and manage catastrophic risk. Researchers across countries and disciplines are beginning to investigate the root causes and common threads of such disasters, reinvigorating the study of catastrophic risk and moving us closer to finding practical solutions for the future.

While conferences dealing generally with the assessment and management of catastrophic risk vulnerabilities occur frequently on both sides of the Atlantic, this conference was unique in that it was specifically designed to encourage US-German international research collaborations.

The steering committee helped put together a tight program of presentations, discussion, and poster sessions, as well as a "World Cafe," which provided an opportunity for early career researchers to network. Steering committee members were:

  • Lee Clarke, Rutgers University
  • Ralph Hertwig, Max Planck Institute for Human Development
  • Andrew W. Lo, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
  • M. Elisabeth Paté-Cornell, Stanford University
  • Ortwin Renn, University of Stuttgart
  • Friedemann Wenzel, Karlsruhe Institute of Technology

Ultimately, nearly 100 German and US scientists came together for the two-and-a-half day program which focused on:

  • The identification and anticipation of risks and catastrophes
  • The evaluation and calculation of risks and coping with uncertainty
  • Proactive risk management
  • Crisis management and crisis communication

In addition, DFG and NSF representatives were present to provide attendees with information about specific funding opportunities, in particular those involving international cooperation.

Overall, this conference was one very small step forward in advancing our ability to anticipate, avoid, and/or reduce the impact of major hazards.
